title: Alexandre Grasseli
text:
Alexandre Grasseli de Souza (born 5 May 1974) is a Brazilian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="manager%20%28association%20football%29">manager</a>, currently in charge of <a href="Cuiab%C3%A1%20Esporte%20Clube">Cuiabá</a>'s under-23 squad.
Managerial career.
Born in <a href="Cachoeiro%20de%20Itapemirim">Cachoeiro de Itapemirim</a>, <a href="Esp%C3%ADrito%20Santo">Espírito Santo</a>, Grasseli was a Physical Education graduate at the <a href="Federal%20University%20of%20Vi%C3%A7osa">Federal University of Viçosa</a>, <a href="Minas%20Gerais">Minas Gerais</a>. He started working for amateur sides Esporte Clube Montanhês de Ervália and Viçosa Atlético Clube, before joining <a href="Am%C3%A9rica%20Futebol%20Clube%20%28MG%29">América Mineiro</a>'s youth setup in 2005.
Grasseli subsequently started working at <a href="Cruzeiro%20Esporte%20Clube">Cruzeiro</a>, being in charge of every squad from the under-15s to the under-20s; in 2011, he was also an assistant manager of the main squad for a brief period. On 8 December of that year, he was named manager of <a href="Tupi%20Football%20Club">Tupi</a> for the <a href="2012%20Campeonato%20Mineiro">2012 Campeonato Mineiro</a>, but was sacked the following 6 February after only two matches.
On 3 October 2012, Grasseli was appointed <a href="Nacional%20Esporte%20Clube%20%28MG%29">Nacional-MG</a> manager for the 2013 campaign, after being an assistant of <a href="Emerson%20%C3%81vila">Emerson Ávila</a> during the year. On 15 January 2014, he moved abroad after being named at the helm of Angolan club <a href="Atl%C3%A9tico%20Petr%C3%B3leos%20de%20Luanda">Atlético Petróleos de Luanda</a>.
Back to Brazil in December 2015, Grasseli took over <a href="Rio%20Branco%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Clube">Rio Branco-ES</a> for the 2016 <a href="Campeonato%20Capixaba">Campeonato Capixaba</a>, but was sacked the following 21 February. For the 2017 season, he was an assistant manager of <a href="Caio%20Autuori">Caio Autuori</a> (at <a href="An%C3%A1polis%20Futebol%20Clube">Anápolis</a>) and <a href="Ney%20Franco">Ney Franco</a> (at <a href="Sport%20Club%20do%20Recife">Sport Recife</a>); he also worked as an interim manager at Anápolis.
Grasseli spent the most of the 2018 season at <a href="CR%20Vasco%20da%20Gama">Vasco da Gama</a>, working as a coordinator of the youth setup. On 29 October of that year, he returned to Cruzeiro, being appointed manager of the under-17s.
On 25 November 2019, Grasseli returned to Vasco after replacing <a href="Marcos%20Valadares">Marcos Valadares</a> at the helm of the under-20s. On 9 October of the following year, he was named interim manager of the first team for the match against <a href="Clube%20de%20Regatas%20do%20Flamengo">Flamengo</a>, in the place of dismissed <a href="Ramon%20Menezes">Ramon Menezes</a>.
Honours.
Cruzeiro
